I regretted it. Here is why.

https://www.bbc.co.uk/ideas/videos/five-charts-that-changed-the-world/p0fb69c1

Who else is feeling just buried under #AIhype after the past few weeks? GPT-4’s “system card”? “Sparks of AGI”? OMG skynet is coming “AI pause” letter? If you’re ready for some cathartic BS shoveling, come join me and @alex as we dig out from under all of this on the next episode of Mystery AI Hype Theater 3000.

Friday April 7 (TOMORROW!)
9:30-10:30am Pacific Time

This feels unreal! After more than 6 years working on WebGPU, it's getting released in Chromium 113, in stable and without flags! It only took a bit longer than the 2 year adventure we initially thought it would be 😅 Read more about it here https://developer.chrome.com/blog/webgpu-release/

We ended up having more than 3000 issues on the WebGPI and WGSL specifications (~400 pages total), as many implementation issues, hundreds (thousands?) of hours standardization meetings with dozens of participants.
Thank you to @fishcharlie for being the first to support https://bird.makeup/ on the highest tier on patreon! Your name is now on the homepage 🎊

title: Sparks of Artificial General Intelligence: Early experiments with GPT-4

last_post.content:
When intelligent people well versed in the technology and its fundamentals arrive at the conclusion that GPT-4 represents a spark of intelligence, rather than an extremely elaborate but still rote memorization machine, I can't help but feel that we might be witnessing the end of human history: we're going to drown in not disinfo after all, but instead in our own inability to recognize human experience from anthropomorphized simulations.
https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12712

title: The Three-Legged Stool: A Manifesto for a Smaller, Denser Internet - Initiative for Digital Public Infrastructure

last_post.content:
Social media is under attack, from state legislators, from the US Congress, from reckless billionaires. At @iDPI_umass
we believe something vastly better is possible - conversations we host, moderate, control and learn from. Read our new manifesto here: https://publicinfrastructure.org/2023/03/29/the-three-legged-stool/

We're proposing a vision of social media that's plural, public-spirited and participatory. It embraces existing platforms as well as creates infrastructure for new, smaller, civic-focused conversations. It relies on tools for accessing social media that give us more control over the voices and topics we here, and gives us the ability to audit and interrogate the algorithms we choose to use to filter and sort what we see.

It's not just a manifesto, but a roadmap. Our civic social platform Smalltown is live in Amherst, and the alpha of our aggregator Gobo should be released later this month. Give our paper a read and let us know if and how you want to be part of this ecosystem.

For projects like deepscatter, moving to webGPU holds huge possibilities going forward because it means we can do arbitrarily complex calculations directly on the GPU, and pass the results back to the browser. Maps like https://atlas.nomic.ai/map/twitter can render 5,000,000 tweets incredibly fast, but push too much compute to CPU--I have a long and growing list of things that are nearly impossible in WebGL (especially the WebGL 1.0 I'm stuck in for deepscatter...) but that should be quite easy in WebGPU.

title: Validated Names for Experimental Studies on Race and Ethnicity

last_post.content:
In many studies, we use names (like vignettes, or applications).
Names bring a lot of baggage with them.

For example, with ‘Hazel’, you already are forming ideas about age, sex, likely SES etc.

Same with Arthur Worthington III,
or Ozamataz Buckshank.

No name is neutral.

In this study, 4,026 people rated 600 names on numerous attributes.

Full data is available here https://osf.io/ahpvq/

Now you can ‘match’ names on all sorts of characteristics

From @cdcrabtree

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41597-023-01947-0

In many studies, we use names (like vignettes, or applications).
Names bring a lot of baggage with them.

For example, with ‘Hazel’, you already are forming ideas about age, sex, likely SES etc.

or Ozamataz Buckshank.

Presents a comprehensive survey of ChatGPT and GPT-4 and their prospective applications across diverse domains.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01852

title: Rethinking the Role of Token Retrieval in Multi-Vector Retrieval

last_post.content:
Rethinking the Role of Token Retrieval in Multi-Vector Retrieval

Presents XTR, ConteXtualized Token Retriever, which introduces a simple, yet novel, objective function that encourages the model to retrieve the most important document tokens first.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01982

title: What It’s Like To Stop Using Google Search - Debugger

last_post.content:
"What It's Like To Stop Using Google Search"

Most of the time I don't notice a thing ...

... because a surprisingly large fraction of my searches are navigational ("where's the site for that *thing* again?") or informational at a level that's trivially easy for any search service at all

So the actual cost of switching is ... pretty low

(DuckDuckGo's my main search these days)

My essay on it: https://debugger.medium.com/what-its-like-to-stop-using-google-search-fbdf9919c551

"Friend" link if you're not a Medium subscriber: https://debugger.medium.com/what-its-like-to-stop-using-google-search-fbdf9919c551?sk=723a09d252b9f8558f08e1551b2b6896

title: For Lower-Income Students, Big Tech Internships Can Be Hard to Get

last_post.content: "[The system] is biased toward students who have more free time to devote to side projects, hackathons and studying for technical interviews—characteristics that conflate privilege with student potential." - Ruthe Farmer of the Last Mile Education fund saying what we all know... https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/05/business/tech-internship-application-grind.html

@electricarchaeo has been tracing the increasingly shocking measures that Carleton is resorting to in order to defeat labor activism. For most of you this probably seems like a distant and trivial issue, but that’s a mistake: it’s a taste of where US higher ed is headed, which means it affects not just faculty but younger generations. [EDIT: Scabs not scans, duh] Scabs taking over courses is one thing, but union-busters commandeering entire course management and learning management systems is another story entirely. https://scholar.social/@electricarchaeo/110152169917530135

title: GitHub - saudiwin/ordbetareg_pack: Repository for R package ordbetareg, used to fit continuous data with lower and upper bounds.

last_post.content: ahhh this new #bayesian ordered beta regression model family (package: https://github.com/saudiwin/ordbetareg_pack; paper: https://doi.org/10.1017/pan.2022.20) is so so neat! I have an outcome bounded at 1 and 32, and the model successfully predicts discrete 1s and 32s, as well as a continuous range in between! #rstats #brms #statsodon

title: GitHub - blackle/mastodon-data-viewer.py: a viewer for mastodon export data

last_post.content:
So are there any good lightweight tools for using your own Mastodon archive? I just want a simple viewer with some basic grep/search and working links to my messages on a live server.

This works pretty well but requires a (simple) install: https://github.com/blackle/mastodon-data-viewer.py

This works without install but was last updated 5 years ago: https://yuzulabo.github.io/Mastodon-Archive-Viewer/

title: MariaDB.com is dead, long live MariaDB.org - Imashadowphantom - Medium

last_post.content:
Sun Microsystems acquired MySQL in 2008 and was then acquired by Oracle in 2010. MySQL’s founder, Monty, forked the code and created a new company called MariaDB.

It’s sadly not gone well and Monty yelled at the current CEO on stage at the last all hands.
https://medium.com/@imashadowphantom/mariadb-com-is-dead-long-live-mariadb-org-b8a0ca50a637

“Despite every single lie to the contrary, despite every single action born of that lie — we are in the midst of rhizomatic care that extends in every direction, spatially, temporally, spiritually.”

title: Opinion | Online Ads Are Serving Us Lousy, Overpriced Goods

last_post.content:
So it turns out that there's science to back up my impression that twitter adds are mostly from from small companies trying to sell overpriced, low-quality goods.

Below, a quote from Julia Angwin's Op Ed (which is very good and well worth reading—and unpaywalled here https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/06/opinion/online-advertising-privacy-data-surveillance-consumer-quality.html?unlocked_article_code=OIFrCYZY-Z_NrkGZjH7-w_qapSe6zAhYXqj5uKOjPw3FBNm9NX4D1elRRzO51YGAekpza5uvXmr5qSAZQ9pBhshxwqyg0mfcEcwkrywhfvFCMHeMFxV7ZRlWbqDPg5QeU-iluF4jtrGJ8l-kHoR5Nd8Vx4u55gEz-8jcwGUMi8XTW0fAFyYcB_NNHcNw7NGSx8I6bizzoVOQ1fCcHHten9j56woNsW8zvZtgDcsTj-9JRRJStOTqf6Tx81wPYxjrrJ8yVPzWrdARTnht1F67-nbReOTka1pk3-Kgbz2r7m3I97U6MvSrqeQEGGwBEyAy2RVi96cXPpxS4Kn2-g3XsgkSEoqb54KYHuHOd6xjFsMQg_wQo17ymRUhXBTEmpcm6r5rSUQn2A&smid=url-share )

A while back @mintynet had his car stolen in a keyless theft. He called me in as a #canbus guru to help work out how exactly the car was stolen, and now we know exactly how they did it and also how to stop them. We call it "CAN Injection 🚘💉" and I've written the whole story up in a blog post: https://kentindell.github.io/2023/04/03/can-injection/

title: ‘Alien Calculus’ Could Save Particle Physics From Infinities | Quanta Magazine

last_post.content: "The secret to fixing a fatal flaw at the heart of quantum theory may lie in three obscure textbooks from the 1980s." Read @charliewood's epic @QuantaMagazine feature about an epic, if obscure, body of work known as "resurgence" that itself is resurging. https://www.quantamagazine.org/alien-calculus-could-save-particle-physics-from-infinities-20230406/

This is exactly how I've been feeling for the last few months. It is becoming almost impossible to keep up with the current pace of research.

#phdlife #machinelearning
---
RT @natolambert
Almost everyone I know working in AI these days feels one step away from total burnout. I took the time to take you behind the curtain and know what people on the state-of-the-art AI are struggling with:

https://robotic.substack.com/p/behind-the-cu…
https://twitter.com/natolambert/status/1643751135856164864

title: LTI Colloquium: Green AI- Efficiency in NLP

last_post.content: First was a stellar talk by Jesse Dodge on efficiency in #NLP at the #CMU Language Technologies Institute. From algorithmic efficiency to computing model carbon output to problems with text scraping datasets, there's a ton in this talk. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZFqm7NnRAe0 (2/10) #sustainability #AI

There are undoubtedly other grassroots organizations in #Tennessee to support right now, but one I know of & admire is #RadioFreeNashville. Their slogan when they launched was "unbuckling the Bible Belt."

There are always pockets of people with good politics even in the reddest of states. If you feel like supporting their mission, feel free to donate and/or boost:

https://radiofreenashville.org/

#radio #CommunityRadio #LPFM #CommunityMedia

title: Google Estimated To Be Paying $15 Billion To Remain Default Search Engine On Safari

last_post.content:
Google pays Apple ~$15 billion/yr to remain the default search engine on iOS.¹ Apple clearly can’t make an AI assistant, and Microsoft clearly can’t make a phone. You gotta suspect talks are happening to cram New Bing into Siri, right?

¹ https://www.forbes.com/sites/johanmoreno/2021/08/27/google-estimated-to-be-paying-15-billion-to-remain-default-search-engine-on-safari/
